items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday evening at 8:00pm, and high tide on Sunday evening at 8:45pm. High water times are measured from Ilfracombe, times of high water will vary along the coast.

Coastal conditions are currently in a period of higher than average tide levels.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue an update on Monday 15th August.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level for Saturday evening at Ilfracombe is 5.05 mAOD, this is 0.08 metres above astronomical tide level. The forecast high tide level for Sunday evening at Ilfracombe is 5.09 mAOD, this is 0.15 metres above astronomical tide level.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high Spring tides forecast at 9:00 PM local time on Saturday 13/08/2022. The Flood Alert will be in force for 2 hours before and after this high water time. Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit. We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by Midday on Sunday 14/08/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Flood alert issued as a result of high tides. Forecast high water is at 21:30 on Saturday 13/08/22 with a level of 7.49 mAOD with force 2 southerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. mAOD is height above average sea level, for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.   Tides will remain high until Monday evening 15/08/22 so this alert will remain in place until then. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be careful along promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Sunday, 14/08/22, or as the situation changes.

High tides are forecast to impact the estuary. Tides will be at their highest between 20:00 and 21:00 today, 13/08/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  We believe there is a possibility of flooding for a series of high tides due over the next 2 days. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.6m at 20:30pm on 13/08, Newport 7.0m to 7.3m at 20:15 on 13/08. The morning tides for the 14/08 between 8:00 and 9:00 are forecast to be lower than the evening tides of 13/08 and not reach flood alert levels. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please call 999 if in immediate danger. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 14/08/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because  between 7.45am and 9.45am tomorrow morning, Sunday 14th August.  We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.52 mAODN at 8.45am, on Sunday 14th August, which is 0.15m above tide tables, wind Force 3, north easterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow Sunday 14th August.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because  between 7.45am and 9.45am tomorrow morning, Sunday 14th August.  We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.52 mAODN at 8.45am, on Sunday 14th August, which is 0.15m above tide tables, wind Force 3, north easterly.  (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow Sunday 14th August.

River levels are expected to be higher than usual at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, and Arpley Bridge as a result of a high tide tomorrow morning (14/08/22). Consequently, flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland is expected between 2:00 am and 3:00 am on 14/08/22 in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry, between 2:00 and 2:30 am, Eastford Road, between 2:15 and 2:45 am, Arpley Bridge, between 2:30 and 3:00 am. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. Flood alerts may also be required for subsequent high tides. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow (14/08/22) at 11am, or as the situation changes.
